repnme.cdata!:
Creating jobs through microfinance in
            Bosnia and Herzegovina

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            creating jobs through microfinance in Bosnia and
            Herzegovina. Before war erupted in Bosnia and Herzegovina in
            1992, the country’s economy was based on heavy and military
            industry, and dominated by several large state-owned
            conglomerates. A major part of this economy was destroyed
            during the conflict. As a result, the country was left
            without the most basic infrastructure and services, and
            suffered from significant unemployment. People had a hard
            time launching new businesses since the commercial banking
            sector was embryonic. The emerging private sector found it
            extremely arduous to access capital, while micro-enterprises
            and low-income clientele found it downright impossible. The
            International Development Association (IDA) financed Local
            Initiatives Microfinance Projects were launched in 1997 to
            raise incomes, develop businesses, and create jobs in Bosnia
            and Herzegovina. IDA provided financing to eight
            micro-credit organizations, invested in building local
            capacity in this new field, and developed a legal and
            regulatory framework so the micro-credit organizations could
            diversify their financing sources and services. The project
            provided financial services to low-income clients and
            micro-entrepreneurs to launch or expand businesses. About
            380,000 micro-credits were disbursed over 10 years from the
            revolving micro-credit. More than 200,000 jobs were created.
            Gender parity achieved. 50 percent of borrowers were women
            and it strengthened women’s role in the family and helped
            support female-headed households, since the war left many
            households without male heads of families.  Overall, the
            projects helped create a sustainable and well performing
            microcredit industry that can meet the needs of
            microenterprises and low income clients in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

docna.cdata!:
Creación de empleo a través del
            microfinanciamiento en Bosnia y Herzegovina

display_title.display_title:
Creating jobs through
            microfinance in Bosnia and Herzegovina : Creación de empleo

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Emergency
            Recovery, Emergency Landmines Clearance, Emergency
            Demobilization and Reintegration, Local Initiative, and
            Republika Srpska Reconsturction Assistance Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Emergency Recovery
            Project (ERP) were substantially relevant  to both Bosnia
            and Herzegovina (BiH's) own reconstruction needs and
            policy and to the Bank's own strategy in support of
            post-conflict recovery. The relevance rating would have been
            higher had it not been for ERP's fourth humanitarian
            objective, which was only modestly relevant to BiH's
            reconstruction. Emergency Landmines Clearance Project: the
            project objectives were modestly relevant to BiH's
            post-conflict recovery program. Both efficacy and efficiency
            in achieving the objectives were negligible; project
            objectives were not met, yet substantial costs were
            incurred. Emergency Demobilization and Reintegration
            Project: for a country in an emergency post-conflict
            situation the project objectives were modestly relevant;
            they emphasized longer-term goals too much, even though they
            neglected demobilization itself. Efficacy in achieving the
            relevant objectives was modest, through the effective
            support the project gave to reintegrating demobilized
            combatants, albeit on a small scale and fewer than targeted.
            Local Initiatives Project: All three project objectives were
            highly relevant to the post-conflict development needs and
            policies pursued in BiH, already more than a year out of the
            war when this project began. Efficacy in achieving these
            objectives was high, being exceeded in the case of the
            setting up the MC0 framework in particular. Republika Srpska
            Reconstruction Assistance Project: For the most part, the
            objectives of this project were substantially relevant to
            Entity and Bank recovery policies.

docna.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Emergency Recovery,

            Reintegration, Local Initiative, and Republika Srpska
            Reconsturction Assistance Projects

repnme.cdata!: Rebuilding lives in Bosnia and Herzegovina

abstracts.cdata!:
During the war in Bosnia and
            Herzegovina, a grenade hit and devastated Milada
            Macanovic's family business. Milada is one of many
            beneficiaries of the World Bank's local initiatives
            project, which over the past five years has helped to
            sustain more than 170,000 jobs in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
            Milada used the credits to keep it fully stocked for the
            neighborhood, and the income derived from it supports her
            family of five. Milada and her husband are among 3.5 million
            Bosnians across the country that are slowly putting their
            lives back together and trying to create a stable future for
            their families.

docna.cdata!: Rebuilding lives in Bosnia and Herzegovina

repnme.cdata!: Bosnia and Herzegovina - Local Initiatives Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated highly
            satisfactory, with a highly likely sustainability, and,
            institutional development impacts were high, due in part to
            the highly satisfactory Bank performance, supportive of
            project design, and implementation to meet operational
            objectives, and, was as well highly instrumental in raising
            co-financing for the project; while, the borrower
            performance was satisfactory, given the appropriate
            institutional structures for project implementation,
            particularly, a very effective agency management, supported
            by professional, and technical staff. Regardless of success,
            lessons address the following. Particularly appropriate, was
            the decision to contract nongovernmental organizations
            (NGOs) as implementing partners, given the post-conflict
            context in the country, for although other legal entities
            were also eligible, NGOs' comparative advantages, met
            the needs for micro-credit services provision. However,
            financial/business skills, and management capacity vary
            across NGOs; most likely, micro-credit organizations
            combining client-driven approaches, with strong business
            management will succeed. This was largely due to the
            investments in technical assistance, and training, which
            strengthened micro-finance institutions' capacity in
            micro-credit operations, and, likewise, their
            performance-based financing provided incentives to
            strengthen their institutional, and financial performance.
